details: LIVA uses production orders for each house separately with two-stage process: 1) Rearing phase (0-24 weeks) costs accumulated then capitalized through GRN into biological assets shown as inventory, 2) Laying phase (25-65 weeks) costs amortized over 40 weeks using Excel calculations and manual JV postings
sap_analysis: Manual biological asset accounting creates compliance risk and prevents real-time visibility into livestock valuation
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with automated biological asset valuation and IAS 41 compliance features
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Agricultural Contract Management with integrated Livestock Management for automated biological asset accounting per IAS 41

topic: Feed procurement and measurement challenges affecting FCR calculations
details: Feed is delivered directly to farms in bulk tankers (32.5 ton capacity) without central storage. Feed measurement done manually using stick/thread dip method in silos. No electronic measuring systems in trucks or silos, leading to feed wastage and inaccurate FCR calculations
sap_analysis: Lack of accurate feed measurement directly impacts critical KPI (FCR) calculations and profitability analysis in poultry operations
recommendation: Implement IoT-enabled weighing systems integrated with SAP, establish proper inventory management at farm level with real-time consumption tracking
best_practice: SAP Livestock Management with integrated IoT sensors for feed consumption monitoring and automatic FCR calculation

topic: Manual Excel processes for critical business functions
details: Manual Excel upload process for route allocation where people punch allocations in Excel which are then uploaded to generate STOs in SAP. Feed management relies entirely on manual calculations and estimates due to lack of integrated measuring systems
sap_analysis: Critical business processes running on Excel indicate significant gaps in SAP process automation and integration
recommendation: Implement SAP standard allocation functionality, integrate weighing systems with SAP through PI/PO or Cloud Integration, eliminate Excel dependencies
best_practice: SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) with integrated scale interfaces and automatic allocation based on business rules

topic: Van sales system performance issues with reporting delays
details: System performance issues identified where reports take 6 months to 1 year to run, sometimes won't run for 1 month due to data volumes. All company codes are in one landscape causing huge data volumes with no data warehousing or separate analytics system
sap_analysis: Performance issues indicate poor system architecture with transactional and reporting systems not separated, causing operational disruption
recommendation: Implement SAP BW/4HANA or SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting, separate transactional from analytical workloads, optimize database and implement archiving strategy
best_practice: SAP BW/4HANA with real-time data replication from S/4HANA for operational reporting and analytics

topic: Production order creation timing and actual vs planned quantities
details: Production orders are created after actual output is known rather than at planning stage. They anticipate expected size based on average weight from farm but actual output varies by weight, requiring different SKUs. Production orders are created after actual output is determined, then consumptions are booked retroactively the next day.
sap_analysis: This retroactive production order creation indicates a disconnect between planning and execution, creating potential material flow and costing issues
recommendation: Implement SAP PP's variant configuration or process orders with co-products/by-products to handle variable yields and multiple output SKUs from single input
best_practice: SAP Process Industries (PI) with recipe management and yield variance handling, or Manufacturing Execution (ME) for real-time capture

topic: Variable output SKUs requiring post-production order creation
details: Production planning is done with estimated average weights, but actual output varies by bird size (1500g to 400g different material codes). Production orders are created after actual production to match real output quantities and weights, with consumption booked retroactively next day.
sap_analysis: This indicates a catch-weight production scenario requiring SAP EWM catch weight management and flexible production order processing
recommendation: Implement SAP catch weight management with production order variants or co-products to handle variable output weights and sizes
best_practice: SAP EWM Catch Weight Management integrated with PP Production Orders for variable weight processing

topic: Multiple Production Orders with Delayed Consumption Booking
details: ENF creates 5 sequential production orders: 1) Egg to DOC (hatchery), 2) DOC to broiler (farms), 3) Slaughtering, 4) Portions and packing, 5) Final packaging. Due to variable output weights (1500g to 400g different material codes), production orders are created after actual output is known, and consumptions are booked retroactively the next day.
sap_analysis: This delayed booking creates timing issues for cost allocation and real-time production visibility. SAP requires consumption booking when materials are actually consumed, not after production completion.
recommendation: Implement SAP Production Orders with planned vs actual consumption tracking, use catch-weight processing capabilities, and implement real-time production confirmation using SAP MES or Plant Connectivity.
best_practice: SAP Catch Weight Management for variable weight products and SAP Manufacturing Execution System (MES) for real-time production confirmation

topic: Same-day processing cycle with manual record keeping
details: The entire processing cycle from live birds to packaged products completes in a single day. Staff manually record what was consumed during processing since the production order is created afterwards.
sap_analysis: Same-day processing with manual records creates risks for accuracy, compliance, and traceability. Manual record-keeping is prone to errors and doesn't provide real-time visibility.
recommendation: Implement mobile data capture during processing with SAP's shop floor control. Use barcode/RFID scanning for real-time production confirmations and material consumption tracking.
best_practice: SAP Manufacturing Execution (ME) with mobile confirmations and automatic goods movements

topic: Production order creation timing and retrospective consumption booking
details: ENF creates production orders AFTER processing is complete based on actual output weights and SKUs. They process birds during the day, see what weight categories and SKUs result, then create production orders the next day and book consumptions retroactively. This is because chicken weights vary significantly and they don't know the exact SKU mix until processing is done.
sap_analysis: This retrospective production order creation and consumption booking creates significant challenges for real-time inventory tracking, cost accounting accuracy, and production planning. It also prevents real-time yield analysis and quality control integration.
recommendation: Implement SAP's catch weight management with production versioning. Use process orders with co-products/by-products to handle variable yields. Set up automatic goods movements during processing with estimated weights, then use catch weight confirmation for final adjustments.
best_practice: SAP ECC/S4 Process Industries catch weight functionality with production versions and automatic goods movement confirmation

topic: Retroactive production order creation for catch weight products
details: Current process involves creating production orders after production is complete to accommodate variable weight outputs. They allow entire production to complete, determine actual output weights and SKUs, then retroactively create production orders and book consumptions the next day. This creates timing gaps between production and system recording.
sap_analysis: This retroactive production recording creates significant gaps in real-time production visibility and inventory accuracy. It prevents real-time costing, capacity planning, and production control.
recommendation: Implement SAP Process Industries (PI) with catch weight management and co-products/by-products functionality. Use production versions with flexible BOMs that can handle variable yields and multiple outputs with different weights.
best_practice: SAP PI Process Manufacturing with Catch Weight Management (CWM) and co-product splitting based on actual yields

topic: Overhead Allocation Inconsistency Between Whole and Portion Products
details: Currently overheads are only charged to portion products but not to whole chicken products, creating inconsistent costing methodology where whole chicken appears artificially cheaper while portions bear full overhead burden.
sap_analysis: This creates distorted product costing where whole chickens show higher margins than reality while portions show lower margins. This impacts pricing strategies and product mix decisions.
recommendation: Implement consistent overhead allocation across all products using SAP's activity-based costing or template allocation. Use production orders with proper routing to ensure all products receive appropriate overhead allocation based on resource consumption.
best_practice: SAP CO-PC Product Cost Controlling with consistent overhead allocation using cost center hierarchies and activity types for fair cost distribution

topic: Overhead allocation methodology discrepancy
details: Overheads are only charged to portion products (30-35% of production) but not to whole chicken products (65-70% of production), creating cost allocation distortion.
sap_analysis: This creates significant costing distortion where whole chicken appears artificially cheap while portions carry full overhead burden, leading to incorrect pricing decisions and profitability analysis.
recommendation: Implement proper overhead allocation across all products using SAP product costing with overhead allocation keys based on production volume, weight, or processing time to ensure accurate cost assignment.
best_practice: SAP Product Cost Controlling (CO-PC) with overhead calculation using assessment cycles and allocation bases to distribute costs proportionally across all output products

topic: Biological asset capitalization and amortization process
details: Manual Excel-based amortization calculations for biological assets (laying hens) with JV postings to SAP. Previously amortized full amount causing profit jumps, now changing to amortize to estimated disposal value. Process involves capitalizing rearing costs (0-24 weeks) then amortizing over laying period (25-65 weeks).
sap_analysis: Manual amortization processes are error-prone and not auditable. SAP has specific functionality for biological assets under IAS 41 that should handle fair value adjustments and systematic amortization automatically.
recommendation: Implement SAP's Asset Accounting (FI-AA) with custom asset classes for biological assets, or use SAP S/4HANA's enhanced biological asset functionality that supports IAS 41 requirements
best_practice: SAP FI-AA Asset Accounting with biological asset classes and automatic depreciation/amortization based on useful life and disposal values

topic: Production order costing methodology inconsistency
details: Currently not charging overheads to whole chicken products, only to portions. This creates inconsistent product costing where whole chickens appear artificially cheaper while portions bear disproportionate overhead costs, distorting profitability analysis and pricing decisions.
sap_analysis: This indicates improper cost allocation in current production orders, leading to inaccurate product profitability. SAP CO-PC (Product Cost Planning) should allocate overheads proportionally across all outputs based on resource consumption or value-based splitting.
recommendation: Implement SAP's joint product costing with value-based allocation to distribute overheads across whole chicken and portions based on market values or resource consumption ratios
best_practice: SAP CO-PC Product Cost Planning with joint product/by-product costing using allocation keys based on market values or quantity ratios

topic: System performance issues affecting reporting and operations
details: Reports take 6 months to 1 year to run, sometimes won't run for 1 month due to data volumes. All company codes are in one landscape causing huge data volumes. No data warehousing or separate analytics system exists, so all reporting load hits the transactional system.
sap_analysis: Critical system architecture issues preventing effective business operations and decision making
recommendation: Implement SAP BW/4HANA or SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting, separate analytics workloads from transactional system, optimize system landscape
best_practice: SAP BW/4HANA for data warehousing, SAC for analytics, system landscape optimization with separate reporting layer

topic: Planning disconnect between capacity-driven production and sales forecast
details: Production planning is driven by farm capacity rather than sales forecast, resulting in systematic overproduction. Sales team operates with promotions to clear excess inventory. The 52-day production cycle makes it impossible to adjust quickly to market demands.
sap_analysis: Fundamental business model misalignment leading to inventory issues, margin pressure, and poor demand-supply matching
recommendation: Implement demand-driven planning with SAP IBP, integrate sales forecasting with production planning, establish make-to-order capabilities where possible
best_practice: SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) for demand sensing and supply planning, S&OP processes

topic: Mixing of different hatchery sources without traceability
details: ENF mixes DOCs from LIVA (40%) with external suppliers (60%) in the same farms and houses, making it impossible to trace performance issues back to specific suppliers or maintain proper batch segregation for quality control.
sap_analysis: Critical traceability gap that prevents quality control, supplier performance evaluation, and root cause analysis
recommendation: Implement strict batch segregation with SAP batch management, separate production orders for different suppliers, maintain traceability from hatchery through processing
best_practice: SAP Batch Management with full genealogy tracking, QM integration with supplier scorecards, separate production planning by source

topic: Feed wastage due to cycle timing misalignment
details: Feed wastage occurs when cycles don't align perfectly - remaining feed from one phase (e.g., half ton to one ton of grower feed) gets transferred to another farm rather than proper cycle counting procedures. Birds consume whatever feed remains in each phase even if they have moved to the next growth stage due to inability to transfer leftover feed between silos.
sap_analysis: Systematic waste built into current process due to poor planning and lack of measurement controls
recommendation: Implement demand-driven planning with accurate consumption forecasting, proper inventory management with measurement systems
best_practice: SAP PP-DS for detailed scheduling, production orders with accurate BOM consumption, inventory management with proper transfer controls

topic: Feed delivery and measurement system gaps
details: Feed is delivered directly to farms in bulk tankers (32.5 ton capacity) without central storage. Each farm has separate silos for different feed phases. Feed measurement is done manually using stick/thread dip method in silos, similar to liquid measurement techniques. No electronic measuring systems in trucks or silos.
sap_analysis: Critical gap in inventory control and planning accuracy. Without proper measurement, FCR calculations are unreliable and feed wastage cannot be controlled.
recommendation: Implement SAP WM with automated weighing integration, establish central stores with proper inventory management, use production orders with accurate component consumption tracking
best_practice: SAP EWM with scale integration, Production Planning with accurate material consumption tracking via production orders

topic: Production order costing methodology for poultry lifecycle
details: Current practice allocates entire cost (including mortality losses) to good production output only. All feed, vaccination, and overhead costs for dead birds are allocated to surviving birds, which increases per-unit cost and FCR calculations. Production orders remain open as WIP until batch completion.
sap_analysis: This indicates standard SAP production order costing with scrapping functionality, but lacks proper mortality cost tracking and FCR optimization capabilities specific to livestock industry
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management for proper biological asset accounting with mortality tracking by reason codes, enabling FCR analysis by feed supplier, house, and flock performance
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management provides specialized production orders for biological assets with mortality reason codes, daily performance tracking, and FCR calculations

topic: FCR calculation methodology in livestock production
details: The discussion touched on FCR (Feed Conversion Ratio) calculation in the context of mortality and cost allocation. The system needs to properly capture input quantities and output quantities to calculate accurate FCR metrics for performance monitoring.
sap_analysis: FCR is a critical KPI in poultry operations and requires accurate feed consumption data, mortality tracking, and weight gain measurements. Current discussion suggests potential gaps in systematic FCR calculation.
recommendation: Implement systematic feed consumption recording, daily weight sampling, and automated FCR calculation through SAP reporting or embedded analytics.
best_practice: SAP Analytics Cloud with embedded analytics or SAP Livestock Management performance indicators

topic: Daily mortality tracking and cost allocation in production orders
details: The discussion revealed that mortality happens daily throughout the production cycle (day 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) with each death having different accumulated costs, but they use one production order for the entire lot. The question was raised about how to properly track mortality costs when birds die at different stages with different cost accumulations.
sap_analysis: This highlights a complex biological asset costing challenge where mortality timing significantly impacts per-unit costs. Standard SAP production orders may not adequately capture the nuanced costing of livestock mortality at different growth stages.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with daily mortality transactions and weight-based costing, or use detailed routing with multiple operations to capture stage-specific mortality costs.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management with biological asset valuation and daily transaction recording

topic: 21-day hatchery cycle with mortality tracking
details: Hatchery operates on fixed 21-day incubation cycle. During this period, mortality and infertile eggs are continuously tracked and scrapped in the production order. Only viable DOCs that successfully hatch are considered good production for costing purposes.
sap_analysis: This biological transformation process with significant waste/mortality requires specialized livestock management capabilities beyond standard manufacturing
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management for biological asset tracking, use time-dependent production orders, implement yield variance tracking against standard hatchability rates
best_practice: SAP Livestock Management with biological asset accounting per IAS 41 standards

topic: Cost allocation methodology for hatchery losses
details: ENF allocates all hatchery costs (including costs of infertile eggs and defective chicks that get scrapped) only to the good chicks that successfully hatch. The scrapped materials don't carry any cost value.
sap_analysis: This is a joint product costing scenario where all input costs are allocated to saleable output, with waste/scrap having zero value. This approach inflates the cost of good chicks but is common in biological processing.
recommendation: Configure SAP with proper joint product costing using allocation keys. Consider implementing activity-based costing for more accurate cost distribution and variance analysis for hatchability performance tracking.
best_practice: SAP CO-PC Joint Product/By-Product Costing with statistical key figures for hatchability rates and cost center accounting for overhead allocation

topic: Immediate production order creation upon DOC receipt
details: Upon receiving eggs at ENF, stores immediately do a goods receipt and the inventory is directly linked to hatchery production orders. There appears to be a streamlined flow from receipt to production without intermediate storage periods.
sap_analysis: This indicates a pull-based production system where receipt triggers immediate production order creation. This is critical for perishable biological materials like hatching eggs where time sensitivity affects hatchability rates.
recommendation: Implement SAP PP production orders with automatic trigger from goods receipt, configure shelf-life management for eggs with FEFO (First Expired, First Out) logic, and establish real-time integration between MM and PP modules for seamless flow.
best_practice: SAP PP Production Order (CO01) with automatic creation via user exits, SAP Batch Management with shelf-life dating for biological materials, and SAP Meat & Fish Management for perishable production planning

topic: Period-level costing for single customer single product scenario
details: Current costing approach works at period level because LIVA has only one customer (ENF) and essentially one product (eggs). This simplifies cost allocation as all production is sold, but creates limitations for future business expansion.
sap_analysis: This simplified costing model will become inadequate as the business grows and adds customers or product variants. It prevents accurate product profitability analysis and customer-specific costing.
recommendation: Implement proper product costing with production orders, cost center accounting, and activity-based costing even for single customer scenario to prepare for future business expansion and enable accurate profitability analysis.
best_practice: SAP Product Cost Controlling (CO-PC) with production order settlement, cost object controlling, and profitability analysis (CO-PA)

topic: Period costing instead of production order costing for eggs
details: LIVA uses period costing for egg production rather than proper production order costing. They create production orders but do not use them for actual cost accumulation and settlement. This means there is no proper cost accounting at the production level.
sap_analysis: This represents a fundamental gap in cost accounting for biological assets. Without proper production order costing, the company cannot track actual costs per unit of production, leading to inaccurate profitability analysis and poor cost control.
recommendation: Implement proper SAP Production Planning (PP) production orders with cost collection and settlement. Use SAP Controlling (CO) Product Cost Controlling for accurate unit costing.
best_practice: SAP Production Order Settlement (KOB1) with proper cost component structure and period-end closing procedures

topic: LIVA biological asset amortization not charged to COGS
details: The biological asset amortization costs for LIVA's livestock are treated as a separate line item in P&L rather than being charged to Cost of Goods Sold (COGS). This means the COPPA (profitability) reports do not reflect the true cost of the products sold, as amortization is excluded from COGS calculations.
sap_analysis: This creates inaccurate product profitability reporting and violates proper biological asset accounting per IAS 41. Management cannot make informed pricing and production decisions without true product costs.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with proper biological asset valuation that includes amortization in product costs, or configure production costing to automatically include amortization as part of COGS through overhead allocation
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management or Product Cost Controlling (CO-PC) with proper overhead allocation and biological asset depreciation integration

topic: Amortization costs excluded from production order costing
details: Amortization costs for biological assets (livestock) are not charged to production orders, creating disconnect between actual production costs and system-captured costs. This affects accurate cost accounting for poultry operations.
sap_analysis: Excluding amortization from production order costing creates incomplete cost capture and may not comply with IAS 41 biological asset accounting standards. This impacts accurate profitability analysis and cost allocation.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management solution with proper biological asset valuation and integrate amortization costs into production order costing through periodic allocation or direct charging methods.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management with biological asset accounting per IAS 41 standards, including fair value adjustments and proper cost allocation to production cycles

topic: LIVA Egg Production Sales Model
details: LIVA operates on a unique sales model where whatever is produced is automatically considered sold - they never maintain egg inventory balances. All egg production is delivered immediately to ENF with no inventory holding.
sap_analysis: This production-to-sales model bypasses standard SAP inventory management but creates challenges for proper cost allocation, inventory valuation, and financial reporting accuracy.
recommendation: Implement proper production orders with goods receipt to inventory, then goods issue for sales delivery to maintain audit trail and enable proper cost accounting
best_practice: SAP Production Planning (PP) with proper inventory management through movement types 101 (GR to stock) and 601 (goods issue for delivery)

topic: Biological asset inventory valuation approach
details: For biological assets, whatever is produced during the laying phase is considered as sold immediately with no ending inventory balance maintained. This eliminates traditional inventory accounting for egg production and creates a direct production-to-sale cost flow.
sap_analysis: This approach violates standard inventory accounting principles and IAS 41 requirements for biological asset fair value measurement. It prevents proper inventory management and cost control.
recommendation: Implement proper inventory accounting with goods receipt for egg production, inventory valuation at standard or moving average price, and proper goods issue for sales with accurate COGS calculation.
best_practice: SAP MM Inventory Management with batch management for egg production, CO-PA Profitability Analysis for proper margin calculation, and SD Sales Order Processing with availability check

topic: LIVA biological asset amortization methodology - manual calculation approach
details: LIVA uses a complex biological asset accounting approach where costs are capitalized during the rearing phase (0-24 weeks) and then amortized over the laying phase (25-65 weeks) at 40 weeks. The amortization is calculated manually in Excel and posted through journal vouchers (JVs). They are changing from full amortization to amortizing to estimated disposal value to avoid profit jumps. Whatever is produced is considered as sold with no ending inventory balance.
sap_analysis: This manual Excel-based biological asset accounting approach creates significant compliance risks for IAS 41 reporting and lacks proper integration with SAP cost accounting. The 'produced = sold' assumption eliminates proper inventory valuation and cost tracking.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management module with proper biological asset accounting using production orders with co-products/by-products for grade A/B eggs, integrated cost estimation runs, and automated amortization through period-end closing activities rather than manual JVs.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management with IAS 41 biological asset valuation, CO-PC Product Costing with activity-based costing for livestock cycles, and FI-AA Asset Accounting for biological asset amortization

topic: Cost allocation methodology for egg production without proper production accounting
details: LIVA derives egg costs by taking total costs (feed, vaccination, amortization from rearing) and dividing by total egg consumption/production, rather than using standard SAP production order costing with actual consumption recording.
sap_analysis: The current approach lacks proper production order costing with actual material consumption, which prevents accurate cost analysis, variance reporting, and proper inventory valuation. This is a fundamental gap in production accounting.
recommendation: Implement proper production order costing with actual material consumption recording, automatic goods issue, and cost center allocation for accurate per-unit costing.
best_practice: SAP Production Planning (PP-SFC) with proper production order settlement and Product Costing (CO-PC) for accurate cost calculation

topic: Manual Excel-based amortization calculation for biological assets
details: LIVA uses Excel to calculate amortization of biological assets (chickens) over 40 weeks from laying phase (weeks 25-65). Previously they amortized the full amount, but now changing to amortize to estimated disposal value to avoid profit jumps. Calculations done in Excel and posted through manual journal vouchers (JVs).
sap_analysis: This manual Excel-based approach creates significant risks for biological asset accounting compliance, audit trail gaps, and potential errors in IAS 41 compliance. The lack of systematic amortization in SAP means no real-time visibility into biological asset values.
recommendation: Implement SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management with proper biological asset accounting per IAS 41. Configure automatic amortization schedules in Asset Accounting or use Production Orders with automatic settlement rules.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management module with integrated biological asset valuation, or configure Asset Accounting (FI-AA) with custom depreciation keys for biological assets

topic: Production order settlement without actual consumption recording
details: The current production order process doesn't follow standard SAP methodology of recording actual consumption and running cost estimation against orders. Settlement and cost allocation happens manually outside the system.
sap_analysis: Without proper production order settlement (TECO, goods issue for actual consumption, and ML21N settlement), cost accounting is inaccurate and lacks audit trail. This fundamentally breaks SAP's cost object controlling.
recommendation: Implement standard SAP production order process with goods issue (261 movement type), confirmation of operations, TECO, and monthly settlement through ML21N with proper variance analysis.
best_practice: Standard SAP Production Order lifecycle: Release → Goods Issue → Confirmation → Settlement → TECO with CO-PC Product Cost Controlling integration

topic: LIVA LIWA biological asset accounting methodology
details: LIVA/LIWA uses a two-stage production accounting process: 1) Rearing phase (0-24 weeks) - costs accumulated in production order then capitalized through GRN into biological assets shown as inventory, 2) Laying phase (25-65 weeks) - costs amortized over 40 weeks using Excel calculations and manual JV postings. Previously full amount was amortized, now changing to amortize to estimated disposal value to avoid profit jumps.
sap_analysis: Current biological asset accounting is heavily manual with Excel-based calculations and manual journal vouchers. This creates audit risk, lacks real-time visibility, and doesn't follow standard SAP production order settlement processes.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with proper biological asset valuation, automated amortization through recurring entries, and standard production order settlement with ML21N for monthly cost allocation.
best_practice: SAP Livestock Management (LS) module with biological asset accounting per IAS 41, automated depreciation using Asset Accounting (AA), and Production Order settlement with overhead allocation

topic: LIVA biological asset amortization methodology details
details: Detailed explanation of how LIVA handles biological asset accounting with two-phase production orders: First order capitalizes all costs from 0-24 weeks rearing phase, then creates biological asset inventory. topic: Biological asset classification and inventory treatment
details: Biological assets are shown as inventory in the books during the 40-week laying period, with costs capitalized from the rearing phase. The assets are classified as 'a kind of inventory' but treated as biological assets under different line items in financial statements.

details: Current process involves capitalizing costs from first 24 weeks (rearing phase) at approximately $100 per chick, then amortizing over 40 weeks (laying phase) using Excel calculations and manual journal voucher (JV) postings. best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Livestock Management with automated biological transformation processes and IAS 41 compliant fair value adjustments

topic: Manual Excel-based biological asset amortization
details: LIVA uses manual Excel calculations for biological asset amortization over 40 weeks (25-65 week laying period). Amortization postings done through manual journal vouchers (JVs). No automated system functionality for livestock asset management or amortization.

topic: Biological asset amortization methodology
details: LIVA uses a complex biological asset accounting methodology where costs from the first 24 weeks (rearing phase) are capitalized as biological assets, then amortized monthly over the subsequent 40 weeks (laying phase). topic: Biological Asset Capitalization Process Gap

best_practice: SAP Livestock Management module with IAS 41 compliant biological asset accounting and automated fair value adjustments

topic: Quality control and mortality management gaps
details: Quality specifications for DOCs started only one month ago. Previously no quality specifications were in place. Reactive testing approach - samples taken after problems identified. High mortality rates contributing to poor FCR performance. No proactive quality control or supplier scorecarding system.

topic: FCR performance gap and feed management control issues
details: Current FCR of 1.7-1.8 versus industry benchmark of 1.4-1.9 (regional standard 1.4). Feed wastage occurs when cycles don't align, and remaining feed from one phase gets consumed by birds in next growth stage, impacting growth rates and FCR performance.

topic: Intercompany transaction complexity without proper planning
details: Complex intercompany relationships where LIVA supplies hatching eggs to ENF, GF supplies feed to both entities, but planning is not centralized. This creates cascading effects when forecasting errors occur at any level, leading to overproduction, excess inventory, and promotional selling at reduced margins.
sap_analysis: Current decentralized planning across three interconnected entities creates significant business risk with profit leakage. Each entity operates independently despite being part of integrated poultry value chain.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) for demand-driven planning across all three entities with centralized S&OP process. Use SAP's Advanced Planning & Optimization (APO) for constraint-based planning considering biological asset lifecycles.
best_practice: SAP IBP with cross-company planning scenarios, SAP S/4HANA Central Finance for real-time consolidation, and livestock management integration for biological asset planning

topic: FCR performance gap and mortality issues
details: Current FCR of 1.7-1.8 versus regional benchmark of 1.4-1.9 with optimal being 1.4. High mortality rates and poor feed management contribute to suboptimal performance. Each 0.1 improvement in FCR worth approximately half a million in savings. Root causes include mixing flocks from different sources, poor feed quality control, and inability to trace performance by supplier.
sap_analysis: FCR is the key performance indicator in poultry operations, directly impacting profitability. The gap between current performance and benchmarks represents significant improvement opportunity, but requires better data collection and process control to achieve.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management for flock tracking and performance monitoring. Use SAP Manufacturing Execution to capture real-time feed consumption and mortality data. Implement batch management to enable supplier performance comparison.
best_practice: SAP Livestock Management with daily performance tracking, SAP QM with statistical process control for feed quality, SAP Batch Management for traceability and performance analysis by source

topic: Co-packer inventory financing without contracts
details: Company is producing for co-packers without confirmed orders or contracts, effectively providing free inventory financing. Materials worth significant value are stored for months without payment, while the company pays storage costs. This represents a major cash flow and profitability issue, with 80% of business being co-packing without proper contractual protection.
sap_analysis: This represents poor commercial terms management and contract lifecycle management. Without proper contract management and advance payments, the company is essentially providing free working capital financing to customers while bearing all inventory risks.
recommendation: Implement SAP Ariba for contract lifecycle management, establish minimum order quantities and advance payment requirements. Use SAP Credit Management for customer credit limits and exposure monitoring. Implement SAP Variant Configuration for customer-specific production only after order confirmation.
best_practice: SAP Contract Lifecycle Management, SAP Credit Management with automatic credit checks, SAP Advanced Available-to-Promise with customer-specific allocation, SAP Customer Hierarchy for contract pricing

topic: Production planning disconnect from sales forecast
details: Fundamental issue where production is driven by farm capacity rather than sales demand, leading to chronic overproduction. Sales forecast becomes irrelevant as farms are filled to capacity regardless of demand. This creates excess inventory, forces promotional selling, and results in margin erosion. The 52-day production cycle makes adjustments impossible once started.
sap_analysis: This represents a complete breakdown of demand-driven planning. The company is operating in 'push' mode rather than 'pull' mode, leading to chronic overproduction and margin pressure. Sales forecasting becomes meaningless when production ignores demand signals.
recommendation: Implement SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) for demand sensing and supply planning. Establish demand-driven production planning with proper S&OP processes. Use SAP APO or IBP for constraint-based planning that considers both capacity and demand.
best_practice: SAP IBP for Supply Chain with demand sensing capabilities, SAP PP/DS for detailed scheduling, SAP S/4HANA Advanced Available-to-Promise for demand-supply matching

topic: Feed inventory measurement and control crisis
details: Critical gap in feed management where bulk feed delivery in 32.5-ton tankers cannot be accurately measured in silos. No electronic measuring systems exist, only manual 'stick/thread dip method' similar to liquid measurement. This leads to feed wastage, inaccurate FCR calculations, and inability to identify which supplier provides better quality feed. Remaining feed from one phase gets consumed in next phase even when birds have outgrown it, impacting growth and FCR.
sap_analysis: This represents a fundamental breakdown in inventory control and production costing. Without accurate feed consumption tracking, the entire cost accounting system is compromised, making it impossible to calculate true production costs or identify process improvements.
recommendation: Implement SAP Production Planning with detailed material consumption tracking, integrated with IoT sensors for real-time silo monitoring. Use SAP Manufacturing Execution System (MES) for shop floor data collection.
best_practice: SAP PP Production Orders with detailed component consumption tracking, SAP Plant Connectivity for real-time data capture from weighing systems, SAP Digital Manufacturing Cloud for IoT integration

topic: Market competitiveness concerns
details: The discussion revealed awareness of performance gaps compared to other markets, with implications for cost competitiveness and business viability in a commodity market where margins are thin.
sap_analysis: Performance benchmarking and continuous improvement are critical in poultry operations. Current regional standards may limit export opportunities and increase vulnerability to imports from more efficient producers.
recommendation: Deploy SAP Analytics Cloud for industry benchmarking and performance management, integrated with operational data from SAP Livestock Management and MSG to drive continuous improvement initiatives.
best_practice: SAP Analytics Cloud industry benchmarking dashboards with automated variance analysis and improvement action tracking

topic: Impact on FCR from improper feed management acknowledged as certain
details: The company acknowledges that their current feed management practices definitely impact their Feed Conversion Ratio (FCR), which is the most critical profitability metric in poultry operations.
sap_analysis: This is a direct admission that current processes are negatively impacting the most important KPI in poultry operations. FCR improvements directly translate to significant cost savings and competitive advantage.
recommendation: Implement comprehensive production planning and control system with real-time monitoring of feed consumption by phase and house. Use SAP Analytics to track FCR by source, house, and batch.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing with real-time analytics and KPI monitoring, potentially SAP Livestock Management if available

topic: Feed phase management problems with single silo system
details: The company has issues with feed phase transitions (starter to grower to finisher) because they use single silos and cannot properly control when different feed types are consumed. Chicks continue eating starter feed even when they should transition to grower feed, impacting growth and FCR.
sap_analysis: This represents a critical production control gap where feed consumption timing cannot be properly managed, directly impacting feed conversion ratios and bird growth performance. The inability to control feed transitions is a major cost driver.
recommendation: Implement proper production order management with material staging and precise consumption tracking. Consider implementing SAP PP-PI for process industries to handle phase-based consumption.
best_practice: SAP Production Planning with material staging and consumption controls, potentially SAP PP-PI for process-specific feed phase management

topic: Multiple hatchery sourcing creates traceability and performance issues
details: Company sources chicks from multiple hatcheries which creates issues with high mortality rate, feed consumption problems, and inability to track performance by source. This makes it impossible to identify which supplier is causing quality issues.
sap_analysis: This indicates a critical gap in supplier quality management and batch traceability that directly impacts production costs and quality KPIs. Without proper segregation and tracking, the company cannot hold suppliers accountable for poor performance.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM with supplier scorecards and batch management to track performance by hatchery source. Use separate production orders for different suppliers to maintain traceability.
best_practice: SAP Quality Management (QM) with Supplier Quality Management and Batch Management functionality to track source-specific performance metrics

topic: Commodity hedging and price risk management absence
details: The company does not practice commodity hedging despite feed being a major cost component and subject to price volatility. The consultant emphasized that without hedging, they are essentially in the feed business rather than poultry business, as feed is the major controllable variable.
sap_analysis: This represents a significant financial risk management gap. SAP provides commodity management and hedging functionality to manage price volatility.
recommendation: Implement SAP Commodity Management for hedging strategies and price risk management, integrated with procurement and financial planning.

topic: Storage and working capital optimization challenges

sap_analysis: This indicates poor inventory management and customer payment terms. SAP can help optimize inventory levels and implement better payment terms management.
recommendation: Implement SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) for inventory optimization and SAP Credit Management for better payment terms enforcement.

topic: Co-packer contract management and advance payment issues

recommendation: Implement SAP Contract Management with mandatory advance payment requirements, proper contract lifecycle management, and integration with production planning to prevent production without confirmed orders.

topic: Budget vs forecast planning methodology issues
details: There's confusion about whether to plan based on annual budget or rolling forecasts. The consultant strongly emphasized that poultry business cannot operate on budget-based production due to short shelf life and market dynamics. Rolling forecasts with 52-day cycles should be used instead.
sap_analysis: This highlights the need for dynamic planning capabilities rather than static budget-based planning. SAP provides rolling forecast functionality that can adapt to market conditions.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP with rolling forecast capabilities integrated with sales and operations planning. Use scenario modeling for different demand patterns.
best_practice: SAP IBP Demand Planning with Rolling Forecast functionality integrated with SAP S/4HANA Sales & Distribution and Production Planning

topic: Production planning based on farm capacity vs sales forecast disconnect
details: There is a fundamental disconnect between production planning and sales forecasting. Production is planned based on farm capacity (filling all available houses) rather than sales demand. The sales team cannot change production mid-cycle due to 52-day lead times. This creates a push market scenario where whatever is produced must be sold, leading to excess inventory and promotions.
sap_analysis: This represents a critical gap in integrated business planning. SAP S/4HANA provides Integrated Business Planning (IBP) and Production Planning & Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS) modules specifically designed to align production capacity with demand forecasts.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP for demand-driven production planning with proper constraint-based planning considering both capacity and demand signals. Use SAP PP/DS for detailed scheduling within biological asset constraints.

topic: System performance issues with reporting

recommendation: Implement SAP BW/4HANA or SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting with proper data extraction from transactional system. Configure data archiving and separate analytics workload.

topic: Co-packer contract and advance payment issues
details: Significant working capital tied up in co-packer inventory without proper contracts or advance payments. Company is storing 9-10 containers outside and paying storage costs for co-packers who haven't paid advances. Recent policy change to require confirmed orders before production.
sap_analysis: This represents a major working capital and cash flow issue with inadequate contract management and credit control processes. The lack of proper purchase order and advance payment processes creates financial risk.
recommendation: Implement SAP Contract Management with mandatory advance payment workflows, credit limit checks, and automatic production release only after confirmed orders with proper payment terms.

topic: FCR performance gap and feed management leakage

topic: Production planning misalignment with sales forecast

topic: Production Planning Disconnect from Sales Forecast
details: There is a fundamental disconnect between production planning and sales forecasting. The discussion reveals that production is driven by farm capacity (filling all houses to maximum capacity) rather than actual sales demand. This creates chronic overproduction leading to excess inventory, forced promotions, and margin erosion.
sap_analysis: This represents a critical S&OP (Sales & Operations Planning) breakdown where production and sales are not aligned. In poultry with short shelf life products, this misalignment causes significant financial impact through waste, markdowns, and suboptimal resource utilization.

topic: Co-packing Business Without Proper Contracts
details: 80% of frozen business is co-packing done without confirmed contracts or purchase orders. Company invests in packaging materials, storage, and production capacity for co-packers who may not take delivery. Recent policy change requires confirmed orders but utilization dropped to 35-60%.

topic: Lack of Traceability Due to Batch Mixing
details: Mixing of different supplier batches (Liva vs external) in same houses and processing, destroying traceability. Cannot identify which supplier caused mortality or performance issues. Industry best practice is to avoid mixing batches from different hatcheries.
sap_analysis: Critical compliance and quality risk - without proper batch segregation and traceability, the company cannot isolate quality issues to specific suppliers or implement supplier accountability.
recommendation: Implement strict batch management with separate production orders for different suppliers. Use SAP QM integration with batch management to maintain supplier-specific traceability throughout the value chain.
best_practice: SAP Batch Management with QM integration, separate handling units for different suppliers, and batch genealogy tracking

topic: Production Planning Disconnected from Sales Forecast
details: Production is capacity-driven rather than demand-driven. Farm capacity determines production volumes regardless of sales forecast, leading to consistent excess supply and need for promotions. 52-day lead time makes it impossible to adjust production mid-cycle based on demand changes.
sap_analysis: This represents a fundamental supply chain planning issue where production planning is not integrated with demand planning, leading to overproduction and margin erosion through promotional activities.
recommendation: Implement integrated demand and supply planning using SAP IBP or APO with proper S&OP process. Link hatchery capacity planning with rolling sales forecasts considering the 52-day planning horizon.

topic: FCR Performance Analysis and Feed Management Controls
details: Current FCR is 1.7-1.8 vs industry benchmark of 1.4-1.9. High mortality and feed wastage due to lack of measuring systems in silos, bulk feed delivery without proper controls, and inability to track feed consumption by house/supplier. Feed represents 95-98% of production cost but company cannot identify which supplier provides better quality feed due to mixed procurement and averaging.
sap_analysis: Critical gap in livestock management - without proper feed tracking and supplier performance analysis, the company cannot optimize their largest cost component. This impacts profitability and operational efficiency significantly.

topic: Industry-Specific FCR Impact Analysis
details: Discussion that 0.1 improvement in Feed Conversion Ratio (FCR) equals approximately half a million in savings, emphasizing the massive financial impact of operational efficiency in poultry business.
sap_analysis: The high financial impact of small efficiency improvements necessitates precise tracking and control of feed consumption, mortality, and weight gain at the house/batch level rather than aggregate reporting.
recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with detailed feed consumption tracking, real-time FCR calculation, and variance analysis at house/batch level with automated alerts for deviations.
best_practice: SAP Livestock Management integrated with Production Orders for precise cost tracking and performance analysis

topic: Push vs Pull Market Production Strategy
details: The company operates in a push market where production capacity drives sales rather than sales forecast driving production. Production runs at 110% capacity regardless of sales forecast, with sales team required to sell whatever is produced. This creates excess inventory and promotional pressure.
sap_analysis: This indicates a fundamental misalignment between production planning and demand planning. SAP S/4HANA's Integrated Business Planning (IBP) and Production Planning modules are designed to align production with demand, not capacity-driven production.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP for demand-driven production planning, integrate sales forecasting with production planning, and establish proper S&OP processes to balance capacity utilization with market demand.
best_practice: SAP IBP Demand Planning and S&OP functionality with integration to PP/DS for capacity-constrained planning

topic: Budget vs Forecast Driven Production Philosophy
details: Strong emphasis that poultry business cannot operate on annual budgets for production decisions - must be forecast-driven due to perishable nature and market dynamics. The consultant stressed this is fundamentally different from other industries.
sap_analysis: This indicates need for rolling forecasts and flexible planning horizons rather than static annual budgets. The planning system must accommodate frequent plan revisions based on market conditions.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP with rolling forecasts and short-term operational planning cycles. Separate financial budgeting (for cash flow management) from operational planning (for production decisions).
best_practice: SAP IBP Demand Planning with weekly/monthly rolling forecasts integrated with SAP S/4HANA Production Planning

topic: Push vs Pull Market Strategy Impact on Production Planning
details: The consultant shared a detailed analogy about push vs pull markets using his experience selling tractors vs bikes. He emphasized that in a push market (like poultry where many competitors exist), companies must be very specific in procurement and planning because products don't 'fly off shelves'. The company appears to be operating in a push market where they produce based on capacity rather than demand, leading to excess inventory and promotional selling.
sap_analysis: This indicates a fundamental disconnect between production planning and demand planning. The company is likely using capacity-driven production rather than demand-driven planning, which creates inventory management challenges and margin pressure.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) for demand-driven production planning. Use SAP's Advanced Planning and Optimization (APO) or IBP to align production capacity with market demand forecasts rather than just filling available capacity.
best_practice: SAP IBP Demand Planning with integrated S&OP (Sales and Operations Planning) to create demand-driven production schedules rather than capacity-driven production

topic: Severe SAP system performance issues affecting operations
details: The current SAP system has severe performance problems with reports taking 6 months to 1 year to run, sometimes not running for a month due to data volumes. All company codes are in one landscape causing huge data volumes without proper data warehousing.
sap_analysis: This represents a critical system architecture failure that prevents effective business operations and decision-making. The lack of data warehousing and proper system sizing is causing business paralysis in reporting and analytics.
recommendation: Implement SAP BW/4HANA or SAP Datasphere for analytics workloads. Separate transactional and analytical systems. Consider system landscape optimization with proper sizing and data archiving strategies.

topic: Manual Excel-based production planning creating inefficiency
details: The company is currently doing production planning through Excel sheets rather than integrated SAP planning. This manual approach is causing planning errors and inefficiencies in a business where precision is critical due to short shelf life and fixed production cycles.
sap_analysis: Manual Excel planning in a complex multi-entity poultry operation with biological assets and short shelf life products is a major operational risk. It prevents real-time visibility, integrated planning across the value chain, and accurate demand-supply matching.
recommendation: Implement SAP PP (Production Planning) with integrated demand management, capacity planning, and MRP. Use SAP S/4HANA embedded analytics for real-time planning visibility and what-if scenarios.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Production Planning with integrated demand and supply planning, using production planning table and capacity leveling

topic: Poultry production cycle lead time constraints
details: The poultry industry operates with a fixed 52-day production cycle (21 days hatching + 31 days raising) that cannot be adjusted mid-cycle. Any changes to production plans require 52 days advance notice. This creates inflexibility in responding to demand changes and makes sales forecasting critical but also creates a push-based system where production capacity drives output rather than demand.
sap_analysis: This fixed lead time constraint makes demand-driven planning extremely challenging and requires sophisticated production planning with long-term forecasting horizons. The current disconnect between sales forecasting and production capacity planning is causing excess inventory and promotions.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) with long-term demand sensing and capacity planning. Use SAP PP-PI production orders with fixed planning horizons. Implement demand-driven MRP with consumption-based planning for raw materials.
best_practice: SAP S/4HANA Production Planning and Control with advanced planning and optimization (APO) for long lead-time industries

topic: Production Planning Disconnect - Capacity vs Sales Forecast
details: The production planning is not driven by sales forecast or budget but by capacity constraints. There's a disconnect where sales forecasting happens after production capacity decisions are made. Production runs on rolling forecast with 52-day cycles.
sap_analysis: This indicates a fundamental planning issue where supply-driven production creates excess inventory and margin pressure. The production planning is not integrated with demand planning.
recommendation: Implement SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) or at minimum SAP PP-DS with proper demand-supply matching. Sales forecast should drive production planning, not vice versa.
best_practice: SAP IBP for demand-driven production planning with S&OP processes, or SAP PP/DS with MRP integration to align production with sales forecast

topic: Centralized planning coordination gap

sap_analysis: Lack of centralized planning across the vertically integrated supply chain creates suboptimization and prevents proper demand-supply coordination

best_practice: SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain with cross-company collaboration and unified planning workspace

topic: FCR performance degradation due to planning gaps

topic: Fixed production cycle constraints vs sales forecast flexibility
details: Production planning has a rigid 52-day cycle (from DOC planning to farm delivery) that cannot be changed mid-cycle, creating disconnect with sales forecasting. best_practice: SAP Livestock Management with integrated production planning and S/4HANA Advanced Available-to-Promise for biological asset planning

topic: Sales vs production planning disconnect
details: There's a fundamental disconnect where sales receives more production than forecasted, and both sales and production teams blame each other for planning inaccuracies. Production operates on farm capacity while sales operates on market demand.
sap_analysis: This indicates a lack of integrated planning between sales forecasting and production planning. Different departments are using different planning bases (capacity vs demand) leading to misalignment.

topic: Production cycle lead time constraints
details: The production cycle has a fixed 52-day lead time (13 days + 21 days hatching + remaining grow-out period), which creates inflexibility in responding to sales forecast changes. Once production is initiated, no adjustments can be made mid-cycle.
sap_analysis: This long lead time with no mid-cycle adjustments creates significant planning challenges and potential mismatches between production output and sales demand. The rigidity of biological production cycles must be reflected in SAP planning parameters.
recommendation: Configure SAP PP with appropriate planning time fences and lot size restrictions that reflect the 52-day biological cycle. Use SAP IBP for demand planning with long-range forecasting capabilities and implement safety stock strategies.

topic: Excess Production Due to Capacity-Based Planning vs Sales Forecast
details: Production planning is driven by farm capacity rather than sales forecast, resulting in consistent overproduction. The farm produces based on available capacity while sales cannot absorb all production, creating excess inventory that must be pushed through promotions.

recommendation: Implement SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) to align production capacity with sales forecasts. Use S&OP processes to balance capacity utilization with market demand. Configure production planning to use sales forecasts as primary driver rather than capacity.
best_practice: SAP IBP for Sales & Operations Planning with demand-driven production planning, capacity optimization, and integrated forecasting across the supply chain

topic: Production Lead Time - 52 Day Planning Horizon
details: Production planning has a 52-day minimum lead time from DOC (Day Old Chick) to finished product. Any changes in demand require minimum 52 days to implement due to the biological nature of poultry production cycle.

topic: Production planning disconnect between sales forecast and actual production

topic: Farm capacity utilization vs forecast mismatch

topic: Production capacity vs sales forecast disconnect

When sources are mixed in same house, they cannot determine which supplier is causing mortality or performance issues.

recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with strict batch segregation by supplier source. Each house should be designated to a single supplier source per cycle to maintain traceability. Use SAP QM integration to track supplier-specific performance metrics (FCR, mortality) by batch.

topic: Excess stock promotional dependency
details: Due to production-driven rather than demand-driven planning, the company frequently has excess fresh chicken requiring promotional activities to move inventory. This is mentioned as a recurring issue affecting profitability.
sap_analysis: Promotional dependency due to excess inventory indicates poor demand-supply alignment and destroys margin structure. This is particularly damaging in fresh poultry with extremely short shelf life.
recommendation: Implement demand-driven production planning using SAP IBP with short-term demand sensing. Use SAP Variant Configuration for flexible production planning based on actual orders and forecasts.

topic: Mixed sourcing without segregation tracking

recommendation: Implement SAP Livestock Management with batch management to maintain separate production orders and batch genealogy for each supplier source. Use SAP QM inspection lots tied to supplier batches.

topic: Production capacity vs sales forecast disconnect
details: There is a fundamental disconnect between production planning and sales forecasting. recommendation: Implement SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) for demand sensing and supply planning. Use SAP S/4HANA Production Planning (PP) with Livestock Management for capacity-constrained planning that considers both farm capacity and market demand.

topic: Flock source mixing preventing performance analysis

topic: Multi-supplier feed mixing preventing quality accountability

topic: Supplier liability and traceability for feed quality control
details: Discussion about the importance of maintaining traceability from feed suppliers to individual farms/houses to establish liability for quality issues. Currently mixing feed from multiple suppliers makes it impossible to trace quality problems back to specific vendors.
sap_analysis: This indicates a critical gap in batch management and supplier quality accountability. Without proper traceability, the company cannot hold suppliers accountable for quality issues that impact FCR and mortality rates.

topic: Mortality reduction through quality specifications
details: Company believes that implementing proper quality specifications for suppliers and making them liable for quality-related losses will significantly reduce livestock mortality rates, which is currently a major cost driver.
sap_analysis: Mortality is a key KPI directly tied to profitability. Company needs robust quality management processes integrated with livestock management to track correlation between supplier quality and livestock performance.

topic: Feed ingredient quality control and supplier liability
details: Discussion about a major quality incident where incorrect feed formulation caused physical deformities in livestock (chicken legs became oversized). Company had claims exceeding one million due to supplier's formulation error. Now implementing quality specifications with suppliers to make them liable for losses from quality issues.
sap_analysis: This highlights critical need for comprehensive quality management integration with procurement. Feed quality directly impacts livestock mortality and FCR ratios. Without proper QM-MM integration and supplier quality agreements, company faces significant financial risk.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM with supplier quality agreements, incoming inspection processes, and automatic batch holds. Use QM-MM integration for certificate-based goods receipt and vendor evaluation based on quality performance.
best_practice: SAP Quality Management (QM) module with Supplier Quality Management, Certificate Management, and Quality Notifications for supplier liability tracking

topic: Historical implementation of feed ingredient quality issues
details: Reference to a previous company where SAP implementation was in progress and they experienced significant problems due to a contaminated feed ingredient, suggesting the critical importance of ingredient quality control and traceability.
sap_analysis: This historical reference highlights the catastrophic impact that a single contaminated ingredient can have across the entire production chain, emphasizing the need for robust quality management and recall capabilities.
recommendation: Implement comprehensive SAP Quality Management with incoming inspection, Certificate of Analysis management, and rapid recall capabilities through batch genealogy
best_practice: SAP QM with Inspection Plans for all feed ingredients, Document Management for COAs, and Batch Information Cockpit for rapid trace-back/trace-forward capabilities

topic: Hatchery mixing practices compromising traceability
details: The company mixes eggs/chicks from different suppliers (both internal Leva and external sources) at the hatchery level, which destroys traceability throughout the production chain. Once mixed, they cannot determine which supplier's material caused performance issues in farms.

best_practice: SAP Batch Management with Batch Where-Used Lists, Production Orders with supplier-specific material flows, and Quality Management with batch-level inspections

topic: Feed supplier performance tracking and vendor liability for mortality
details: Discussion revealed that the company procures from multiple feed suppliers but cannot differentiate performance between vendors due to bulk delivery and mixed usage. sap_analysis: This indicates a critical gap in vendor performance management and traceability. The inability to track vendor-specific performance impacts cost optimization and quality control in the poultry value chain.

best_practice: SAP Supplier Evaluation with KPI dashboards for FCR tracking, Quality Info Records for vendor specifications, and Batch Determination with vendor segregation

topic: Mixed hatchery sources creating traceability issues
details: The company mixes eggs from different hatcheries (internal Liva production and external suppliers) at the hatchery level, making it impossible to trace performance back to specific sources. topic: Mixed hatchery sources creating traceability challenges
details: ENF sometimes mixes day-old chicks from their own Liva hatchery with external suppliers in the same farm houses. topic: Parent stock quality performance issues from external supplier
details: The company has identified significant performance issues with parent stock received from external supplier 'Bhutu'. After investing in 3-5 farms, they noticed poor performance and higher mortality rates. This affects 15-16% of their procurement which is substantial.

recommendation: Implement SAP QM with supplier scorecards, quality agreements, and certificates of analysis. Use SAP Livestock Management to track performance by parent stock source and establish quality-based supplier evaluation criteria.
best_practice: SAP QM Quality Management with Supplier Quality Management, integrated with SAP Livestock Management for performance tracking by genetic source

topic: Recent implementation of supplier specifications for quality control

sap_analysis: This represents a fundamental gap in procurement quality management that is just being addressed. Without specifications in purchase orders, there's no basis for quality control or supplier accountability.

best_practice: SAP MM with quality info records, inspection plans mandatory for critical materials, and quality agreement management

topic: Reactive quality testing approach causing delayed issue identification
details: Current quality testing is reactive - issues are only identified after problems occur, with a 20-22 day delay for lab results. This means problems in hatching eggs are discovered after the eggs are already in production, making it impossible to prevent mortality and quality issues.
sap_analysis: This reactive testing approach creates major traceability and quality control gaps. By the time quality issues are identified, the affected eggs are already in the hatching process, leading to higher mortality rates and FCR problems.
recommendation: Implement SAP Quality Management (QM) with proactive inspection plans at goods receipt, integrated with batch management for full traceability from supplier through production.
best_practice: SAP QM with inspection plans, usage decisions, and quality notifications integrated with batch management and production orders

topic: Quality testing delay impacting business decisions
details: Lab testing for egg quality takes 20-22 days to get results, but by then eggs are already in production and issues have manifested. This creates a reactive rather than preventive quality management approach.
sap_analysis: This indicates a critical gap in real-time quality management integration with production planning. The delay prevents proactive quality decisions and supplier performance management.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM with real-time quality inspection points, automated supplier scorecards, and integration with procurement to prevent poor quality materials from entering production
best_practice: SAP QM Certificate Management for supplier qualification, Inspection Planning with sampling procedures, and Quality Notifications for rapid issue response

topic: Delayed reactive testing approach for DOC quality
details: Lab testing for DOCs is reactive - they wait 20-22 days after receiving to take samples and test, only testing when problems are already identified. This means quality issues are discovered too late to prevent impact on production.
sap_analysis: This reactive testing approach means quality problems are identified after biological processes have already been affected, making it impossible to prevent production losses. Early detection is critical in livestock management.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM with immediate inspection procedures upon DOC receipt, using skip-lot logic for trusted suppliers and 100% inspection for new/problematic suppliers. Link test results to batch records for traceability.
best_practice: SAP QM Inspection Planning with immediate sampling procedures and quality notifications (QM02) for non-conformances

topic: Recently implemented DOC quality specifications with poor supplier compliance

sap_analysis: This indicates a critical quality management gap where supplier quality agreements and compliance tracking are not systematically managed. The lack of historical quality specifications suggests reactive rather than preventive quality management.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM Supplier Quality Management with vendor scorecards, quality agreements, and automatic blocking of non-compliant suppliers. Use QM inspection lots for incoming DOCs with statistical process control.

topic: Disease contamination cycle impact
details: When dangerous diseases are detected, they stay in the same plant and require 2-3 cycles to clean up, indicating significant biosecurity challenges and extended contamination periods.
sap_analysis: This indicates serious biosecurity issues where disease contamination persists across multiple production cycles, suggesting inadequate cleaning/disinfection procedures and lack of proper facility isolation protocols.
recommendation: Implement SAP EHS (Environment, Health & Safety) for biosecurity management with proper facility isolation, cleaning validation procedures, and equipment/facility status tracking to prevent cross-contamination.

topic: Reactive quality testing approach
details: Laboratory testing is purely reactive - they only test after problems are identified, waiting 20-22 days to take samples. This means by the time issues are detected, significant damage has already occurred to flock performance and mortality rates.
sap_analysis: Reactive quality testing in poultry operations is extremely problematic as diseases and quality issues compound rapidly in live animals. By the time issues are detected at 20-22 days, entire flocks may be compromised.

topic: Recently implemented DOC quality specifications

topic: Reactive quality testing approach
details: The laboratory testing process is reactive rather than preventive. They wait for problems to occur before conducting tests, and testing cycles take 20-22 days which is too long for fast-moving poultry production cycles. This creates gaps in quality control and traceability.
sap_analysis: This reactive approach creates quality control gaps in a fast-moving biological asset environment where production cycles are 15-65 weeks. The 20-22 day testing cycle is too slow for poultry operations where mortality and disease can spread rapidly.
recommendation: Implement SAP QM with preventive inspection plans, automatic sampling schedules, and real-time quality notifications. Use SAP Plant Maintenance for equipment calibration and SAP Livestock Management for health monitoring integration.

sap_analysis: This indicates a need for robust quality management integration with livestock management processes. Early detection of quality issues in biological assets is critical for preventing major losses in poultry operations.

topic: Recognition that feed consumption management directly impacts profitability

topic: Manual vaccination tracking with no system integration

details: Discussion about quality control issues with Day Old Chicks (DOC) and hatchery conditions affecting mortality rates and FCR performance. Client acknowledging that there may be process rectifications needed in DOC quality checks and hatching conditions.

topic: Feed phase transition control issues

topic: Lack of accurate quantity measurement at delivery

topic: Production planning disconnect from sales forecasting
details: Current production planning is based on farm capacity rather than sales forecasting, leading to consistent oversupply and promotion-driven sales. DOC procurement and production cycles operate independently from demand planning, causing excess inventory and margin pressure.
sap_analysis: This represents a fundamental disconnect between supply planning and demand planning, leading to overproduction, waste, and reduced profitability. The short shelf life of fresh products makes this particularly problematic.
recommendation: Implement SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) to align production capacity with demand forecasts. Set up demand-driven production planning with safety stock calculations based on forecast accuracy.
best_practice: SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP), SAP Advanced Planning and Optimization (APO), Demand-Driven Material Requirements Planning (DDMRP)

topic: Feed storage and measurement challenges with bulk delivery
details: Feed is delivered in bulk tankers (32.5 ton capacity) directly to farm silos without intermediate storage or accurate measurement. Measurement is done manually using stick/thread dip method. This creates control issues as exact consumption per house cannot be tracked, leading to waste and inaccurate FCR calculations.
sap_analysis: The lack of accurate measurement and central storage control creates significant operational and financial risks. Bulk delivery without proper measurement makes inventory management, waste tracking, and cost allocation extremely difficult.
recommendation: Consider implementing IoT-enabled silo monitoring systems integrated with SAP. Alternatively, move to bag-based delivery for better quantity control. Implement SAP Extended Warehouse Management for better inventory tracking.
best_practice: SAP Extended Warehouse Management, SAP Manufacturing Integration and Intelligence (MII) for IoT sensor integration, Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS) for accurate consumption tracking

topic: FCR monitoring and feed supplier performance evaluation
details: Feed Conversion Ratio (FCR) monitoring is done house by house for different suppliers. Current FCR is around 1.7, which is considered acceptable for the region but not optimal.
